trans-unit.source: Cross-Validate Model
trans-unit.target: Cross-Validate Model

trans-unit.source: Cross-validates parameter estimates for classification or regression models by partitioning the data
trans-unit.target: Cross-validates parameter estimates for classification or regression models by partitioning the data

trans-unit.source: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="EA496474-D04C-474F-896F-3F4531CD8BE0" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Machine Learning / Evaluate</legacyLink>
trans-unit.target: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="EA496474-D04C-474F-896F-3F4531CD8BE0" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Machine Learning / Evaluate</legacyLink>

trans-unit.source: Module Overview
trans-unit.target: Module Overview

trans-unit.source: You can use <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> to test an untrained classification or regression model.
trans-unit.target: You can use <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> to test an untrained classification or regression model.

trans-unit.source: The result of cross-validation can help you interpret the quality of the data set and understand whether the model is susceptible to variations in the data.
trans-unit.target: The result of cross-validation can help you interpret the quality of the data set and understand whether the model is susceptible to variations in the data.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> takes an untrained classification or regression model and a training data set as an input.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> takes an untrained classification or regression model and a training data set as an input.

trans-unit.source: It returns evaluation results by cross-validation fold.
trans-unit.target: It returns evaluation results by cross-validation fold.

trans-unit.source: It also returns the scored dataset.
trans-unit.target: It also returns the scored dataset.

trans-unit.source: Understanding Cross-Validation
trans-unit.target: Understanding Cross-Validation

trans-unit.source: Cross validation randomly splits the training data into a number of partitions, called <newTerm>folds</newTerm>.
trans-unit.target: Cross validation randomly splits the training data into a number of partitions, called <newTerm>folds</newTerm>.

trans-unit.source: The algorithm defaults to 10 folds if you have not previously partitioned the dataset.
trans-unit.target: The algorithm defaults to 10 folds if you have not previously partitioned the dataset.

trans-unit.source: Then, the module sets aside the data in one fold to use for validation (called the <newTerm>holdout fold</newTerm>), and uses the remaining folds to train a model.
trans-unit.target: Then, the module sets aside the data in one fold to use for validation (called the <newTerm>holdout fold</newTerm>), and uses the remaining folds to train a model.

trans-unit.source: The model is validated on the hold-out fold.
trans-unit.target: The model is validated on the hold-out fold.

trans-unit.source: After models for each fold have been trained and validated, <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> generates a set of performance metrics and scored results for all folds.
trans-unit.target: After models for each fold have been trained and validated, <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> generates a set of performance metrics and scored results for all folds.

trans-unit.source: The other way that you can evaluate a model is to divide the data into a training and test set using <link xlink:href="70530644-c97a-4ab6-85f7-88bf30a8be5f" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Split</link>, and validate the model on the training data.
trans-unit.target: The other way that you can evaluate a model is to divide the data into a training and test set using <link xlink:href="70530644-c97a-4ab6-85f7-88bf30a8be5f" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Split</link>, and validate the model on the training data.

trans-unit.source: However, the advantage of using <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> instead is that cross-validation measures the performance of the model with the specified parameters in a bigger data space – basically it uses the entire training dataset for both training and evaluation, instead of some portion of it.
trans-unit.target: However, the advantage of using <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> instead is that cross-validation measures the performance of the model with the specified parameters in a bigger data space – basically it uses the entire training dataset for both training and evaluation, instead of some portion of it.

trans-unit.source: In contrast, if you validate a model by using data generated from a random split, typically you evaluate the model only on 30% or less of the available data.
trans-unit.target: In contrast, if you validate a model by using data generated from a random split, typically you evaluate the model only on 30% or less of the available data.

trans-unit.source: However, because <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> trains and validates the model multiple times over a larger dataset, it is much more computationally intensive and takes much longer than validating on a random split.
trans-unit.target: However, because <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> trains and validates the model multiple times over a larger dataset, it is much more computationally intensive and takes much longer than validating on a random split.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, we recommend that you use <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> in the initial phase of building and testing your model, to evaluate the goodness of the model parameters, assuming that computation time is tolerable, and then train and evaluate your model using the established parameters with the <link xlink:href="5cc7053e-aa30-450d-96c0-dae4be720977" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Train Model</link> and <link xlink:href="927d65ac-3b50-4694-9903-20f6c1672089" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Evaluate Model</link> modules.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, we recommend that you use <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> in the initial phase of building and testing your model, to evaluate the goodness of the model parameters, assuming that computation time is tolerable, and then train and evaluate your model using the established parameters with the <link xlink:href="5cc7053e-aa30-450d-96c0-dae4be720977" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Train Model</link> and <link xlink:href="927d65ac-3b50-4694-9903-20f6c1672089" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Evaluate Model</link> modules.

trans-unit.source: How to Use Cross-Validate Model
trans-unit.target: How to Use Cross-Validate Model

trans-unit.source: <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> is simple to use, though it can take a long time to run if you use a lot of data.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> is simple to use, though it can take a long time to run if you use a lot of data.

trans-unit.source: First, connect the untrained model to evaluate.
trans-unit.target: First, connect the untrained model to evaluate.

trans-unit.source: The model can be untrained because <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> automatically trains the model as part of evaluation.
trans-unit.target: The model can be untrained because <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> automatically trains the model as part of evaluation.

trans-unit.source: Connect the training dataset.
trans-unit.target: Connect the training dataset.

trans-unit.source: If you want to be able to repeat the results exactly, set a value for the <ui>Random seed</ui> parameter.
trans-unit.target: If you want to be able to repeat the results exactly, set a value for the <ui>Random seed</ui> parameter.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> randomly splits the training data into 10 folds.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> randomly splits the training data into 10 folds.

trans-unit.source: A fold is a subset of the original dataset.
trans-unit.target: A fold is a subset of the original dataset.

trans-unit.source: If you want to use some other number of partitions, use <link xlink:href="a8726e34-1b3e-4515-b59a-3e4a475654b8" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Partition and Sample</link> to create the desired number of partitions.
trans-unit.target: If you want to use some other number of partitions, use <link xlink:href="a8726e34-1b3e-4515-b59a-3e4a475654b8" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Partition and Sample</link> to create the desired number of partitions.

trans-unit.source: In each iteration over the dataset, <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> uses one fold as a validation dataset, and uses the remaining folds to train a model.
trans-unit.target: In each iteration over the dataset, <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> uses one fold as a validation dataset, and uses the remaining folds to train a model.

trans-unit.source: Each of the 10 models is tested against the data in all the other folds.
trans-unit.target: Each of the 10 models is tested against the data in all the other folds.

trans-unit.source: After all iterations are complete, <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> creates a set of performance metrics for all models, as well as scores for the entire dataset.
trans-unit.target: After all iterations are complete, <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> creates a set of performance metrics for all models, as well as scores for the entire dataset.

trans-unit.source: To view the results, in the experiment, right-click the output port of the <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> module and select <ui>View Results</ui>.
trans-unit.target: To view the results, in the experiment, right-click the output port of the <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> module and select <ui>View Results</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Results
trans-unit.target: Results

trans-unit.source: <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> returns a set of evaluation metrics for each fold, and a summary for the entire dataset.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> returns a set of evaluation metrics for each fold, and a summary for the entire dataset.

trans-unit.source: The first output dataset contains scores and probabilities for the model, as well as the source data for each row.
trans-unit.target: The first output dataset contains scores and probabilities for the model, as well as the source data for each row.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Fold assignment.</embeddedLabel> Indicates which fold each row of data was assigned to.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Fold assignment.</embeddedLabel> Indicates which fold each row of data was assigned to.

trans-unit.source: During cross-validation.
trans-unit.target: During cross-validation.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Scored Labels.</embeddedLabel> The predicted value for each row.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Scored Labels.</embeddedLabel> The predicted value for each row.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Scored Probabiities.</embeddedLabel> A probability score for the current predicted value.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Scored Probabiities.</embeddedLabel> A probability score for the current predicted value.

trans-unit.source: The second output contains a summary report.
trans-unit.target: The second output contains a summary report.

trans-unit.source: A careful review and comparison of fold results can help you identify irregularities in the dataset or the model.
trans-unit.target: A careful review and comparison of fold results can help you identify irregularities in the dataset or the model.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Fold number.</embeddedLabel> An identifier for the current fold results.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Fold number.</embeddedLabel> An identifier for the current fold results.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Number of examples in fold.</embeddedLabel> The count of rows assigned to each fold.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Number of examples in fold.</embeddedLabel> The count of rows assigned to each fold.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Model.</embeddedLabel> The type of learner that was used in creating the models.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Model.</embeddedLabel> The type of learner that was used in creating the models.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Metrics.</embeddedLabel> The metrics that are provided depend on the type of model that you are evaluating.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Metrics.</embeddedLabel> The metrics that are provided depend on the type of model that you are evaluating.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Classification models</embeddedLabel>: Precision, recall, F-score, AUC, average log loss, and training log loss metrics.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Classification models</embeddedLabel>: Precision, recall, F-score, AUC, average log loss, and training log loss metrics.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Regression models</embeddedLabel>: Mean absolute error, root mean squared error, relative absolute error, and relative squared error metrics
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Regression models</embeddedLabel>: Mean absolute error, root mean squared error, relative absolute error, and relative squared error metrics

trans-unit.source: For an example of how to interpret the results of cross-validation, see <externalLink><linkText>this Model Gallery example</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/Experiment/d9d3c11b360343be9c9cbdc6a3981350</linkUri></externalLink>, of cross-validation on a binary classification model.
trans-unit.target: For an example of how to interpret the results of cross-validation, see <externalLink><linkText>this Model Gallery example</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/Experiment/d9d3c11b360343be9c9cbdc6a3981350</linkUri></externalLink>, of cross-validation on a binary classification model.

trans-unit.source: By looking at the results for each of the hold-out folds, you can learn these tihngs:
trans-unit.target: By looking at the results for each of the hold-out folds, you can learn these tihngs:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Fold 7</embeddedLabel> is in the first row.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Fold 7</embeddedLabel> is in the first row.

trans-unit.source: From the name, Fold 7, you can tell that the model was trained on the data in folds 0-6 and folds 8-9.
trans-unit.target: From the name, Fold 7, you can tell that the model was trained on the data in folds 0-6 and folds 8-9.

trans-unit.source: The model was then evaluated using the data in Fold 7.
trans-unit.target: The model was then evaluated using the data in Fold 7.

trans-unit.source: For Fold 7, the <ui>Scored Probability</ui> is 0.132534, and the <ui>Scored Labels</ui> is <=50K.
trans-unit.target: For Fold 7, the <ui>Scored Probability</ui> is 0.132534, and the <ui>Scored Labels</ui> is <=50K.

trans-unit.source: This means that the Fold 7 model predicts the label of this particular row as <=50K, with a predicted probability of 0.132534.
trans-unit.target: This means that the Fold 7 model predicts the label of this particular row as <=50K, with a predicted probability of 0.132534.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the second row is assigned to <embeddedLabel>Fold 1</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the second row is assigned to <embeddedLabel>Fold 1</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, this particular model was trained on the data in folds 0 and folds 2-9.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, this particular model was trained on the data in folds 0 and folds 2-9.

trans-unit.source: This model also predicts the value of <ui>Scored Labels</ui> for this row as <=50K, but in this model, the <ui>Score Probability</ui> is 0.074428.
trans-unit.target: This model also predicts the value of <ui>Scored Labels</ui> for this row as <=50K, but in this model, the <ui>Score Probability</ui> is 0.074428.

trans-unit.source: Examples
trans-unit.target: Examples

trans-unit.source: For examples of how cross-validation is used in machine learning, see these sample experiments in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:
trans-unit.target: For examples of how cross-validation is used in machine learning, see these sample experiments in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:

trans-unit.source: <externalLink><linkText>Cross validation for binary classifier</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525734</linkUri></externalLink>: Demonstrates how to use cross-validation with a binary classification model
trans-unit.target: <externalLink><linkText>Cross validation for binary classifier</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525734</linkUri></externalLink>: Demonstrates how to use cross-validation with a binary classification model

trans-unit.source: <externalLink><linkText>Cross Validation Regression: Auto Imports Dataset</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525735</linkUri></externalLink>: Demonstrates how to use cross validation with regression models and how to interpret the results
trans-unit.target: <externalLink><linkText>Cross Validation Regression: Auto Imports Dataset</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525735</linkUri></externalLink>: Demonstrates how to use cross validation with regression models and how to interpret the results

trans-unit.source: Technical Notes
trans-unit.target: Technical Notes

trans-unit.source: It is a best practice to normalize datasets before using them for cross-validation.
trans-unit.target: It is a best practice to normalize datasets before using them for cross-validation.

trans-unit.source: Because <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> trains and validates the model multiple times, it is much more computationally intensive and takes longer time than validating on random split to complete.
trans-unit.target: Because <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> trains and validates the model multiple times, it is much more computationally intensive and takes longer time than validating on random split to complete.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you use <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> to establish the goodness of the model given the specified parameters.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you use <ui>Cross-Validate Model</ui> to establish the goodness of the model given the specified parameters.

trans-unit.source: We also recommend that you use <link xlink:href="038d91b6-c2f2-42a1-9215-1f2c20ed1b40" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Sweep Parameters</link> to identify the optimal parameters.
trans-unit.target: We also recommend that you use <link xlink:href="038d91b6-c2f2-42a1-9215-1f2c20ed1b40" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Sweep Parameters</link> to identify the optimal parameters.

trans-unit.source: Exceptions
trans-unit.target: Exceptions

trans-unit.source: Exception
trans-unit.target: Exception

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if no features were provided for a given user or item.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if no features were provided for a given user or item.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if argument is not a number.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if argument is not a number.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if argument is Infinity.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if argument is Infinity.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if one or more specified columns of data set couldn't be found.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if one or more specified columns of data set couldn't be found.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if one or more of inputs are null or empty.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if one or more of inputs are null or empty.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if parameter is greater than or equal to the specified value.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if parameter is greater than or equal to the specified value.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if parameter is not in range.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if parameter is not in range.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if the learner that is passed to the module has an invalid type.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if the learner that is passed to the module has an invalid type.
